content.raw:
Ok, thanks!

1. Add a border around the X and Y "zones" that can be used to receive variables. Just so it's clear where the user can drag the variables.
2. Add more padding to the pills so the text doesn't come too close to the borders. 
3. Give the X,Y area the same background color as the canvas.
4.  Move the Settings icon to the left so it doesn't touch the down arrow (I remember this not being possible, but thought I'd try anyway)
5. Make the + button square instead of rectangular
content.html:
Ok, thanks!

  1. Add a border around the X and Y "zones" that can be used to receive variables. Just so it's clear where the user can drag the variables.
  2. Add more padding to the pills so the text doesn't come too close to the borders.
  3. Give the X,Y area the same background color as the canvas.
  4. Move the Settings icon to the left so it doesn't touch the down arrow (I remember this not being possible, but thought I'd try anyway)
  5. Make the + button square instead of rectangular

content.raw:
Does it make sense being able to drag the same variable to the `y` variable pill container twice?

![plot.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1992425063-plot.png)

I guess it makes sense if later you add a different variable into each `Real Time Factor` for creating two multi-variable plots.
content.html:
Does it make sense being able to drag the same variable to the y variable pill container twice?

I guess it makes sense if later you add a different variable into each Real Time Factor for creating two multi-variable plots.

content.raw: ya makes sense. I was thinking of a case where user renames a variable in the container, e.g. Cat to Dog, and then drag in a Dog variable. These two will produce the two different plots. Maybe we should prevent this and just show a warning saying that variable with name already exists?
content.html: ya makes sense. I was thinking of a case where user renames a variable in the container, e.g. Cat to Dog, and then drag in a Dog variable. These two will produce the two different plots. Maybe we should prevent this and just show a warning saying that variable with name already exists?

content.raw: I think there are use cases where this makes sense, never mind.
content.html: I think there are use cases where this makes sense, never mind.

content.raw: Yeah, a duplicate name warning should do the trick.
content.html: Yeah, a duplicate name warning should do the trick.

content.raw:
I implemented duplicate name checking in 52dc7c6.

You can have same variables within a container (they are in different plots) but you cannot have same variable within a multi-variable pill.

Name checking is done against the name of the variable when its first dragged in from the left palette - this is assumed to be unique. Users are free to edit the variable pill text later and it won't affect the unique name.
content.html:
I implemented duplicate name checking in 52dc7c6.

You can have same variables within a container (they are in different plots) but you cannot have same variable within a multi-variable pill.

Name checking is done against the name of the variable when its first dragged in from the left palette - this is assumed to be unique. Users are free to edit the variable pill text later and it won't affect the unique name.

content.raw: Looks better.
content.html: Looks better.

content.raw: Is there any way of removing one variable from the `y` pill container without clearing all fields? Being able to drag the variable from the pill container to the left panel would be super nice.
content.html: Is there any way of removing one variable from the y pill container without clearing all fields? Being able to drag the variable from the pill container to the left panel would be super nice.

content.raw: In the design spec, clicking a variable selects it. Pressing Delete deletes it.
content.html: In the design spec, clicking a variable selects it. Pressing Delete deletes it.

content.raw: Good to know, thanks.
content.html: Good to know, thanks.

content.raw: I mentioned this to Ian in person but I'll write it here for the record too. When you add a variable into an existing one, the pill doesn't highlight as the design mentions.
content.html: I mentioned this to Ian in person but I'll write it here for the record too. When you add a variable into an existing one, the pill doesn't highlight as the design mentions.

content.html: I'll implement this later and submit it in a future pull request
